member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Gauge.LinearRangeBarOptions.StartSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the start size of the embedded range bar. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A value that indicates the start size of the embedded range bar. The default value is 1.0.

remarks.para: The value of can't be less than 0.0 or greater than 1.0, the value will be coerced if it is set outside the range [0.0, 1.0]. When the property value is 1, the begining end of the range bar takes the full height of the tick bar.
See here for more information on how to use this property.

member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

See here for more information on how to use this property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Gauge.LinearScaleBase.MarkerBarSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the embedded marker bar. This is a dependency property.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.Gauge.LinearScaleBase.MarkerBarHorizontalOffsetProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Gauge.LinearScaleBase.MarkerBarHorizontalOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal offset of the embedded marker bar. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A value that represents the horizontal offset of the embedded marker bar. The default value is 0.

remarks.para: See here for more information on how to use markers. Note that this property has no effect on the marker bar if the scale is set to . For vertical scales, when this property is 0, the left of the marker bar is aligned to the left of the tick bar. A negative value moves the marker bar towards the left and a positive value moves the marker bar towards right.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.Gauge.LinearScaleBase.MarkerBarVerticalOffsetProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Gauge.LinearScaleBase.MarkerBarVerticalOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical offset of the embedded marker bar. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A value that represents the vertical offset of the embedded marker bar against the tick bar. The default value is 0.

remarks.para: See here for more information on how to use markers. Note that this property has no effect on marker bar if the scale is set to . For horizontal scales, when this property is 0, the top of the marker bar is aligned to the top of the tick bar. A negative value moves the marker bar up and a positive value moves the marker bar down.

member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Gauge.Shapes.BaseGaugeShape.Padding
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies the padding of this gauge shape from all sides. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A value that specifies the distance from the edge. The default value is 0.0.

example.para:
The following sample demonstrates the effect of the property:
<Window x:Class="GaugeShapes.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:eo="http://schemas.essentialobjects.com/wpf/" Title="MainWindow" Height="300" Width="350">
<Grid> <Grid Width="220" Height="220"> <gs:QuarterGaugeShape Fill="#282923" /> <gs:QuarterGaugeShape Fill="#3A3A38" Padding="20" /> </Grid> </Grid>
</Window>
The previous XAML markup will render the following result:

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Gauge.CircularLabelOptions.StringFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets a composite string that specifies how to format the labels of a . This is a dependency property.
member.value: A composite string that specifies how to format the labels of a .

example.para: The following example applies the currency format to the major labels of a .
example.code:
<Window x:Class="Wpf.Window3" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:eo="http://schemas.essentialobjects.com/wpf/" Title="CircularScale Demo" Height="400" Width="600"> <Grid> <eo:CircularScale Minimum="0" Maximum="100" MajorInterval="10" MinorInterval="2" Width="300" Height="300" ShowFirst="False"> <!-- define the rings that will hold the ticks and labels --> <eo:CircularScale.RingDefinitions> <eo:RingDefinition Width="15" Height="15" /> <eo:RingDefinition Width="150" Height="150" /> </eo:CircularScale.RingDefinitions>
<eo:CircularScale.MajorLabelOptions> <eo:MajorCircularLabelOptions Ring="1" StringFormat="c" /> </eo:CircularScale.MajorLabelOptions>
</eo:CircularScale> </Grid> </Window>

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.Gauge.CircularScale
member.summary: Represents a circular scale.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.Gauge.CircularScale.StartAngleProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Gauge.CircularScale.StartAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates the start angle of scale. This is a dependency property.
member.value: The default value is 0.

remarks.para: A circular scale starts at the value specified by the value of StartAngle and ends at the value specified by the value of .
Note that the values of the angle increase clockwise and decrease counterclockwise.

The following XAML code demonstrates how to create a half-top gauge scale:
<eo:CircularScale Minimum="0" Maximum="12" MajorInterval="1" ShowMinorTicks="false" StartAngle="180" EndAngle="360" />

member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether to show major or minor tick marks. This is a dependency property.
member.value: One of the enumeration values. The the default is .

remarks.para: A can be used to display either major or minor ticks, but not both. In order to display both major and minor ticks, you must use two control.

When this property is set to , it generates minor ticks at but skips at . This is necessary so that you can stack major and minor ticks together without having both major and minor ticks at the same spot.
For example, for the following :
It will display ticks at 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 9, but skip 0, 5, 10.
Because of this, if you specify the same value for and , then it will not display any minor ticks because all the tick points will be considered major thus be skipped.

member.summary: Provides data related to dragging an item over another .
member.remarks: When dragging an item over another , one or two target items may be involved. If the item being dragged is right on top of another item, then that item is the primary target item (as identified by and ). In addition to the primary target item, if the mouse position is close to the top or bottom edge of primary item, the next item on that edge will be returned through and . The default drop behavior in this case is to insert the item in between these two items.

member.name: M:EO.Wpf.ItemsControlHelper.InsertItemBetween(System.Object,System.Windows.UIElement,System.Windows.UIElement)
member.summary: Insert an item between two adjacent items.
member.param: The first item container of the two ajacent item.
The second item container of the two ajacent item.
member.returns: The item container of the newly inserted item.

remarks.para: Both targetContainer1 and targetContainer2 must be an item of an EO.Wpf or a . For items of other controls, please use instead.

This method is typically used to handle a drop event where user drags an item from one and drop it in between two items of another or the same . The two adjacent items are usually items returned by ItemDropEventArgs.TargetItemContainer1 and ItemDropEventArgs.TargetItemContainer2. These two items can be on the same level (for example, items in a ), or can be on different level (for example, items in a ). In case they are on different levels, the two items are still visually next to each other (for example, the last child element of a previous item and item next to the parent item).

remarks.para: container must be an item container from an EO.Wpf or .

This function may return a different value than for a . If container is a , then either returns the (for top level items) or the parent (for child items), whereas this function always returns the control.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.MaskedEdit.TextProperty
member.summary: Identifies the property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.MaskedEdit.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the text.

remarks.para: Use this property to gets or sets the current text for the control. The text of the control is the of all child controls concatenated together, including those for s. For example, a control used to enter date value may define the following segments:
remarks.code: <eo:MaskedEdit PromptChar="_"> <eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment Digits="2" TabPattern="/" MinValue="1" MaxValue="12" AutoPadZeros="True"></eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment> <eo:StaticMaskedEditSegment Value="/"></eo:StaticMaskedEditSegment> <eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment Digits="2" TabPattern="/" MinValue="1" MaxValue="31" AutoPadZeros="True"></eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment> <eo:StaticMaskedEditSegment Value="/"></eo:StaticMaskedEditSegment> <eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment Digits="4" MinValue="1900" MaxValue="2100" AutoPadZeros="True"></eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment> </eo:MaskedEdit>
remarks.para: For the above , its may return something like "01/12/2013". Note the value of (the two "/"s) are returned as well.

When setting this property, the control use a number of methods try to determine the best way to split a single string into different segments, and assign each segment to the corresponding 's property. For the date sample above, this can be successfully achieved by matching the text of the two first. However this may not be possible for some other cases. Consider the following control which contains two :

It is possible for user to enter "12" in the first segment and "345" in the second segment, thus property returns "12345". However if you set to "12345", all 5 digits will be filled into the first , with the second being set to empty. To avoid such problems, you can use to explicitly insert separators between the of each .

remarks.para: If the segment is empty, then returns null. If the segment is not empty, then the following table describes the data type of :

item.description: Any object type. does not perform any conversion of .

description.para: The type is System.Decimal. It is possible for you to assign a value of compatible type, for example, a System.Int32 to the property. In that case it will be converted into System.Decimal.
The of a always conforms with the segment's and .

item.description: A System.Integer that represents the index of the option selected (when no option is selected, returns null).

description.para: A System.String value that represents the content of the segment.
The of a may not conform the in the following two scenarios:

list.item: If the text user entered does not match the , then character at the unmatching position will be replaced with space character. For example, if user enters "1a2" for mask "000", then will return "1 2", where there is a space between '1' and '2'.

The text user entered has matched the so far, but it's not completed yet. For example, mask "000" represents three required digits. If user has only entered two digits "12", it matches the mask so far but is not complete. In this case will return "12" (however will be false for that segment).

item.description: A string value directly as user entered. A does not perform any kind of in place conversion of user entered value. However it does automatically update its property and property as user types.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.MaskedEditSegment.TabPattern
member.summary: Gets or sets a regular expression pattern that is used to determine whether a keyboard event automatically advance to the next segment.

remarks.para: If a character user typed matches this pattern, then the focus is automatically advanced to the next section as if user has pressed the tab key.
Consider the following example:
remarks.code: <eo:MaskedEdit PromptChar="_"> <eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment Digits="2" TabPattern="/" MinValue="1" MaxValue="12" AutoPadZeros="True"></eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment> <eo:StaticMaskedEditSegment Value="/"></eo:StaticMaskedEditSegment> <eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment Digits="2" TabPattern="/" MinValue="1" MaxValue="31" AutoPadZeros="True"></eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment> <eo:StaticMaskedEditSegment Value="/"></eo:StaticMaskedEditSegment> <eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment Digits="4" MinValue="1900" MaxValue="2100" AutoPadZeros="True"></eo:NumericMaskedEditSegment> </eo:MaskedEdit>
remarks.para: In the above example, is set to "/". If user types "/" before filling the first , the focus will automatically advance to the third (The second is skipped since it's a non-editable segment.

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.MaskMaskedEditSegment
member.summary: Represents a that restricts user input based on a given mask.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.MaskMaskedEditSegment.MaskProperty
member.summary: Identifies the property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.MaskMaskedEditSegment.Mask
member.summary: Gets or sets the input mask.

remarks.para: The following table lists all valid mask:

item.description: Digit, required. This element will accept any single digit between 0 and 9.
Digit or space, optional. Plus (+) and minus (-) signs are also allowed.
Letter, required. Restricts input to the ASCII letters a-z and A-Z. This mask element is equivalent to [a-zA-Z] in regular expressions.
Letter, optional. Restricts input to the ASCII letters a-z and A-Z. This mask element is equivalent to [a-zA-Z]? in regular expressions
Shift down. Converts all characters that follow to lowercase.
Shift up. Converts all characters that follow to uppercase.
Disable a previous shift up or shift down.
Escape. Escapes a mask character, turning it into a literal. "\\" is the escape sequence for a backslash.
Literals. All non-mask elements will appear as themselves within MaskedEdit. Literals always occupy a static position in the mask at run time, and cannot be moved or deleted by the user.

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.MonthPicker
member.summary: Represents a control that can be use to select a year and a month.
member.remarks: See here for more information on how to use this control.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.MonthPicker.MonthLinkButtonFormatProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.MonthPicker.MonthLinkButtonFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format of the month. This is a dependency property.

remarks.para: The control uses this format string to format , then use the result string as the month link button text. The default value is "MMM", which returns the abbreviated name of the month. For example, for December, it returns "Dec" if the current culture is English.

Note that standard DateTime format string has priority over custom DateTime format string. For example, "M" represents the month as a number from 1 through 12 as a custom DateTime format string, but it also represents date and time format string defined by the current property as a standard DateTime format string. As such if is set to "M", it will be interpreted as standard DateTime format string, thus returning a string like "April 10" instead of "4". In order for the format string to be interpreted as custom format string, you can prefix it with an empty string literal. For example, instead of setting this property to "M", you can set it to "''M". Note the empty string literal (two single quotes) before the "M".

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.MonthPicker.MonthButtonFormatProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.MonthPicker.MonthButtonFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format of the month. This is a dependency property.

remarks.para: The control uses this format string to format the value corresponding to the first day of the month, then use the result string as the month button text. The default value is "MMMM", which returns the abbreviated name of the month. For example, for December, it returns "December" if the current culture is English.

Note that standard DateTime format string has priority over custom DateTime format string. For example, "M" represents the month as a number from 1 through 12 as a custom DateTime format string, but it also represents date and time format string defined by the current property as a standard DateTime format string. As such if is set to "M", it will be interpreted as standard DateTime format string, thus returning a string like "April 10" instead of "4". In order for the format string to be interpreted as custom format string, you can prefix it with an empty string literal. For example, instead of setting this property to "M", you can set it to "''M". Note the empty string literal (two single quotes) before the "M".

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.OpacityConverter
member.summary: This utility class is used to apply an opacity value to a solid color, it is mainly used in XAML to construct gradient brushes based on solid colors.
member.remarks:
In order to use , you can first define it in your resource:
<eo:OpacityConverter x:Key="half_transparent" Opacity=".5" />
Then use it in later in your XAML. For example, the following XAML uses the above converter to construct a half-transparent gradient:
<LinearGradientBrush StartPoint="0,0" EndPoint="0,1"> <GradientStop Offset="0.0" Color="{TemplateBinding Foreground, Converter={StaticResource half_transparent}}" /> <GradientStop Offset="0.5" Color="Transparent" /> </LinearGradientBrush>

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.Primitives.LimitedSpacePanel
member.summary: Represents a that tries to arrange its children in one of the two ways: either tries to hide items that does not fit, or tries to shrink child items to make them fit.

remarks.para: functions like a horizontal , except that if the total child item width exceeds the total available width, it applies one of the following two strategies:

item.para: If is set to true, it tries to automatically shrink each child item to make them fit. In this case only a portion of each child item will be shown. This behavior is demonstrated in the following image:

In the above picture, the has two items. However the full width of the two items are greater than the total available width in the panel, so the panel tries to shrink both items. In this case both items are being clipped off on the right, as the shown in the picture that the letter "m" is not fully displayed;
If is set to false, it hides those items that can not be fully displayed altogether. This behavior is demonstrated in the following image:
In the above picture, the has two items, however because the second item can not completely fit into the visible area, the only displays "Item 1". "Item 2" is hidden (it's is set to ).

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.Primitives.TabItemBorder
member.summary: A element that is suitable to draw tab item borders.

remarks.para: A is derived from the standard WPF control but provides the following benefits:
A control always draw the bottom border outwards instead of inwards. For example, the following code:
Produces the following result:
The following XAML and image demonstrates how to use and to create a slanted left and right slope:
The following XAML and image demonstrates the rotating feature by setting to Rotation90 (rotating clockwise 90 degrees):
remarks.code: <eo:TabItemBorder BorderBrush="Green" BorderThickness="1" CornerRadius="10" LeftSlopeAngle="50" RightSlopeAngle="95" Rotate="Rotate90" />
remarks.para: Note when a is rotated, it does not rotate its contents. This allows you to keep the orientation of the tab item contents, for example, the orientation of the images inside the tab item.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Primitives.TabItemBorder.LeftSlopeAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle of the left slope.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Primitives.TabItemBorder.RightSlopeAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle of the right slope.
member.remarks: The default value is 90. Valid value must be between 0 and 180.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Primitives.TabItemBorder.Rotation
member.summary: Gets or sets the rotation of the tab item.
member.remarks: The rotation rotate tab item shape, including and , but not margins and paddings. The contents of the content is not rotated either.

member.summary: Sets or gets the UI culture for the EO.Wpf library.

remarks.para: EO.Wpf uses various string literals, such as a "Close" tooltip for a "Close" button. Setting this property to switch the language for these string literals. EO.Wpf.dll has translation for the following languages:
Where "XX" are possible language variations. For example, both "fr-FR" (France) and "fr-CA" (Canada) will load the French translation.

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.UnitType
member.summary: Represents the kind of value that a object is holding.

remarks.para: In XAML, a percentage value is expressed as 0.01 or 1%. The first notation is true up to 0.99, 100% can't be expressed as 1 that value will be interpreted as a fixed value.

member.summary: The value is expressed in device-independent units.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.UnitType.Percentage
member.summary: The value is a expressed as a percentage of the available space.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Unit.EffectivePercentValue
member.summary: Gets the effective percent value as a value between 0 and 1.

remarks.para: If is less than 1, then it is directly interpreted as the effective value. For example, if is 0.5, then the effective value is 0.5 (50%). However if is greater than 1, then this function returns divided by 100. For example, if is 50, then this function returns 0.5 (50%).

member.exception: In case is not equal to .

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.Bitmap
member.summary: Represents a control that displays a bitmap based on its pixel size instead of device independent size.
member.remarks: WPF's control displays an image based on the image's device independent size, which can be different than the image's pixel size if the image's DPI is not the same as the target screen's DPI, in which case the image will be automatically scaled according to the target screen's DPI settings, which often cause blurry images. EO.Wpf control disables this logic and always renders the image using its original pixel size.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the button is in checked state.
member.remarks: This property does not automatically change the behavior or the appearance of the button. However it is often desired to have a bitmap button to display a different image when in "checked" or "pushed" state. In such case you can utilize this property to distinguish a different state of the button. For example, you can set this property to true in code, then use it as a trigger to switch in your xaml.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.ShowWeekNumber
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether week numbers will be shown on each month within the . This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to show week numbers; otherwise false. The default value is false.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.EnableWeekSelector
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether week selection is enabled or not. This is a dependency property.
member.value: True to enable week selection; otherwise false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: Note that week selection can only be activated if the is set to or .
Note that in order to use week selection after enabling it, must be set to true.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.EnableMonthSelector
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether month selection is enabled or not. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to enable month selection; otherwise false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: Note that month selection can only be enabled if the is set to or .
After enabling month selection and the previous condition is met, a appears at the top left corner of the as illustrated in the following image:
Note that the month can be styled via .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.WeekNumberFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates the strategy to use while computing the week number. This is a dependency property.
member.value: The default value is .

remarks.para: Note that for the WeekNumberFormat property to be used, the property must be set to true.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.HighlightWeekends
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the weekend dates within the calendar should be highlighted. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to highlight weekends; otherwise false. The default is false. The default style highlights the weekend days as red when this property is set to true. You can customize to customize the highlight style.

remarks.para: The list of weekend days can be specified via the collection.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.HighlightToday
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether today is highlighted.
member.value: true if the current date is highlighted; otherwise false. The default value is true.
member.remarks: You can customize to customize the highlight style.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.FirstDayOfWeek
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates the day to use as the starting day of the calendar week. This is a dependency property.
member.value: One of the values. The default value is .

member.summary: Gets or sets a collection of values that represents the weekend days.
member.value: By default the collection is initialized using the following values: and .

example.para: The following example changes the weekend days to and .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.IsInMultiMonthView

member.value: true if the is currently displaying more then one month; otherwise false. The default value is false.

remarks.para:
The following image illustrates the in multi-month view.
The previous image can be created with the following XAML markup:
<eo:Calendar MonthRows="2" MonthColumns="2" />

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.DisabledDaysOfWeek
member.summary: Gets or sets which days in the week should be disabled. This is a dependency property.

remarks.para: The following code disables Monday and Friday:

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.Calendar.DisabledDates
member.summary: Gets a collection of disabled date ranges.

remarks.para: Use this property to specify a collection of disabled date in the calendar.
The following code demonstrates how to set this property in XAML:
remarks.code: <eo:Calendar.DisabledDates> <!--A DateRange that covers the whole year of 2011 --> <eo:DateRange StartDate="2011/1/1" EndDate="2011/12/31"> </eo:DateRange> <!-- A DateRange that covers a single date --> <eo:DateRange StartDate="2012/3/1" /> </eo:Calendar.DisabledDates>
remarks.para: The following code demonstrates how to use this property in code:
remarks.code:
'Add a DateRange that covers the whole year of 2011 Calendar1.DisabledDates.Add(New DateRange(New DateTime(2011, 1, 1), New DateTime(2011, 12, 31)))
'Add a DateRange that covers a single date Calendar1.DisabledDates.Add(New DateTime(2012, 3, 1))

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.DatePicker.PickerFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets a string value that represents the format of the value. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A string value that represents the format of the value. The default value is "d".
member.remarks:
The control can recognize common patterns, the following table illustrates the list of patterns supported:
Picker Format Description
d Short date pattern.
D Long date pattern.
f Full date/time pattern (short time).
F Full date/time pattern (long time).
g General date/time pattern (short time).
G General date/time pattern (long time).
M or m Month/day pattern.
O or o Round-trip date/time pattern.
R or r RFC1123 pattern.
s Sortable date/time pattern.
t Short time pattern.
T Long time pattern.
u Universal sortable date/time pattern.
U Universal full date/time pattern.
Y or y Year month pattern.
For more information on standard format string see this MSDN page.
If none of the standard format strings suit a user particular needs. A custom Picker format can be used, the following XAML usses a custom picker format values:
<eo:DatePicker SelectedDate="1/1/2013" PickerFormat="yyyy -- MMM -- dd dddd" />
The following table lists all the specifiers that can be used:
SpecifierDescription
dDisplays the current day of the month, measured as a number between 1 and 31, inclusive. If the day is a single digit only (1-9), then it is displayed as a single digit.
ddDisplays the current day of the month, measured as a number between 1 and 31, inclusive. If the day is a single digit only (1-9), it is formatted with a preceding 0 (01-09).
dddDisplays the abbreviated name of the day for the specified DateTime. It uses the list from the equivalent object.
ddddDisplays the full name of the day for the specified DateTime. It uses the list from the equivalent object.
MDisplays the month, measured as a number between 1 and 12, inclusive. If the month is a single digit (1-9), it is displayed as a single digit.
MMDisplays the month, measured as a number between 1 and 12, inclusive. If the month is a single digit (1-9), it is formatted with a preceding 0 (01-09).
MMMDisplays the abbreviated name of the month for the . It uses the from the equivalent object.
MMMMDisplays the full name of the month for the . It uses the from the equivalent object.
yDisplays the year for the specified DateTime as a maximum two-digit number. The first two digits of the year are omitted. If the year is a single digit (1-9), it is displayed as a single digit.
yyDisplays the year for the specified DateTime as a maximum two-digit number. The first two digits of the year are omitted. If the year is a single digit (1-9), it is formatted with a preceding 0 (01-09).
yyyDisplays the year for the , as a three-digit number. If the year is less than three digits in length, then preceding zeros are appended as necessary to make the displayed year three digits long.
yyyyDisplays the year for the , including the century. If the year is less than four digits in length, then preceding zeros are appended as necessary to make the displayed year four digits long.
yyyyyDisplays the year for the , as a five-digit number. If the year is less then five digits in length, then preceding zeros are appended as necessary to make the displayed year five digits long.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.RadialPanel.ShowRingsProperty
member.summary: Identifies the dependency property. This property is for visual debugging. When it is set to true Ellipses are drawn to show the location of the Rings.

members.member:
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the should draw a line on the inner and outer edge of the ring to help visually see the rings boundaries. This is a dependency property.
true is radial panel rings arcs are shown; otherwise false. The default value is false.
This property should be used as a design tool to debug issues related to rings structure.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.RadialPanel.AutoDistribute
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether a will automatically compute the property of each child or not. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to auto distribute the children of this instance; otherwise false. The default value is true.

remarks.para: Note that the child's property is affected by the and properties.

The following example demonstrates how to use this property, to center a group of controls along a ring without specifying the angle for each button:
<eo:RadialPanel Width="150" Height="150" AutoDistribute="True" StartAngle="0" EndAngle="180"> <eo:RadialPanel.RingDefinitions> <eo:RingDefinition eo:RadialPanel.RingAlignment="Center" Width="40" Height="40" /> </eo:RadialPanel.RingDefinitions>
<eo:Button>1</eo:Button> <eo:Button>2</eo:Button> <eo:Button>3</eo:Button> <eo:Button>4</eo:Button> </eo:RadialPanel>

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.RadialPanel.IsDirectionReversedProperty

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.RadialPanel.IsDirectionReversed
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the arrangement of children is inverted or not. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to invert the direction of children arrangement; otherwise false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: Note that by default a arranges its children from left to right. When is set to true, it arranges its children from right to left.

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.RotationMode
member.summary: Specifies how children are rotated within their containing in the .

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.RotationMode.None
member.summary: No rotation is performed on the child control. As a result, the element will always be horizontally aligned.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.RotationMode.Radial
member.summary: The child control will be rotated the same value as its value or the internally computed one in case is set to true. As a result, the left side of the control always points to the center of the ring with the right side of the control pointing outwards.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.RotationMode.Circular
member.summary: The child control will be rotated so that the bottom of the control points to the center of the ring, while the top points outwards.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.IsReadOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the is read-only to a user interacting with the control. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true if the spin edit control is read-only to the user; otherwise false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: Note that in case the IsReadOnly property is set to true, the can't be modified by the user, but it can always be modified via C# code.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.IsInteger
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the value is an integer. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true if the value is an integer; otherwise false. The default value is false.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.Text
member.summary: Gets the of the as a . This is a dependency property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.DecimalDigits
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of decimal places to use. This is a dependency property.
member.value: The number of decimal places to use. The default value is 0.

remarks.para: Note that the value of DecimalDigits has no effect if the property is set, instead use the provided instance to to set the number of decimal digits.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.Delay
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of time, in milliseconds, the 's waits, while its pressed, before it starts repeating. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A time delay in milliseconds. The default is the system key press delay. For more information, see .

remarks.para: The value must be non-negative.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.Interval
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of time in milliseconds between repeats when users holds down the increase/decrease button that causes the commands to repeat. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A time in milliseconds between commands that changes the Value of a . The default value is the system key repeat rate.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.ValueFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format to apply to the value. This is a dependency property.
member.value: One of the enumeration values that is used to format the value of the . The default value is .

remarks.para: Note that you can use the ValueFormat and properties to provide advanced formatting. for more information see .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.NumberFormatInfo
member.summary: Gets or sets the object used to format the value of the . This is a dependency property.
member.value: The default value is null.

remarks.para: The control provides and that offers basic formating, if advanced formatting is required an instance of the class can be used.
Note that the NumberFormatInfo property is used together with to format the ; for example, if you want to change the way currencies are formatted, make sure that the property is set to .
The following example uses an instance of the to override the default currency symbol and also use the minus sign (-) instead of the parenthesis for negative format:
remarks.code: <Window x:Class="Test.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:eo="http://schemas.essentialobjects.com/wpf/" xmlns:g="clr-namespace:System.Globalization;assembly=mscorlib" Title="MainWindow" Height="250" Width="350"> <Window.Resources> <g:NumberFormatInfo x:Key="CustomValueFormat" CurrencyNegativePattern="1" CurrencySymbol=""></g:NumberFormatInfo> </Window.Resources> <StackPanel Margin="10"> <eo:SpinEdit HorizontalAlignment="Left" Minimum="-10" Maximum="10" Value="-1" Width="100" ValueFormat="Currency" NumberFormatInfo="{StaticResource CustomValueFormat}" /> </StackPanel> </Window>
remarks.para: The above code produces the following result:

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.ValueFormatString
member.summary: Gets or sets the value format string.

remarks.para: Set this property to format the value of the when the is not in edit mode. For example, setting this property to "C2" can format value 1345.6 to "$1,345.60".
When this property is set, is ignored.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.RangeIndicatorStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the applied to the range indicator control of this spin edit. This is a dependency property.

example.para: The target type of this style is . The following example, which sets a new style for the SpinEdit range indicator element:
example.code: <Window x:Class="Test.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:eo="http://schemas.essentialobjects.com/wpf/" xmlns:g="clr-namespace:System.Globalization;assembly=mscorlib" Title="MainWindow" Height="250" Width="350"> <Window.Resources> <g:NumberFormatInfo x:Key="CustomValueFormat" CurrencyNegativePattern="1" CurrencySymbol=""></g:NumberFormatInfo> </Window.Resources> <StackPanel Margin="10"> <eo:SpinEdit HorizontalAlignment="Left" Minimum="-10" Maximum="10" Value="-1" Width="100" ValueFormat="Currency" NumberFormatInfo="{StaticResource CustomValueFormat}" /> </StackPanel> </Window>
example.para: The above code produces the following result:

member.summary: Retrieves the keyboard repeat-delay setting, which is a value in the range from 0 (approximately 250 ms delay) through 3 (approximately 1 second delay). The actual delay associated with each value may vary depending on the hardware.

member.name: M:EO.Wpf.SpinEdit.GetKeyboardSpeed
member.summary: Retrieves the keyboard repeat-speed setting, which is a value in the range from 0 (approximately 2.5 repetitions per second) through 31 (approximately 30 repetitions per second). The actual repeat rates are hardware-dependent and may vary from a linear scale by as much as 20%.

An control. Clicking the button switch the dock view into auto hide mode.
An control. Clicking the button closes the active item in this .
An control. Clicking the button maximize a floated window. This element is only visible when the 's is set to and the window is currently not maximized.
An control. Clicking the button to restore a floated window. This element is only visible when the 's is set to and the window is currently maximized.
A element used to holds the tab buttons for all the s.

member.summary: Gets or sets style for the border around the when the is in auto hide mode.
member.remarks: When a is in auto hide mode, a tab button is created for each . Moving mouse over the tab button will display the corresponding . A is being placed around the auto hide area to distinguish it from other UI elements. This style applies to that element.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.DockContainer.AutoHideTrayButtonStyle

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.DockContainer.TabButtonStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the style for the tab buttons at the top or the bottom of the .
member.remarks: When multiple s are placed in a regular (when is false), the displays a tab button for each at the bottom of the dock view. For a document view (when is true), the tab buttons are displayed at the top of the view. User can use these buttons to switch dock items. This style applies to these buttons.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.DockContainer.AllowMultiDocumentViews
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to allow multiple document views.

remarks.para: The default value is false, in which case a single can have at most one with its set to true. If you try to set a second 's to true when is false, an exception is thrown.

When is set true, user can also create new document views by dragging and dropping a to an area that would create a new view. For example, user can drag and drop a from an existing document view and drop it on the left edge of the . This would create a new document view that docks to the left edge of the , with the new document view contains the single dropped .
When is false, creating a second document view is not allowed, thus such drop operation would not be allowed, so user can only drop the back to the original document view.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether a tooltip that contains the current value of the derive control displays when the is pressed. If a tooltip is displayed, this property also specifies the placement of the tooltip.
member.value:
One of the
values that determines where to display the tooltip with respect to the of the derived control, or that specifies to not show a tooltip. The default is
, which specifies that a tooltip is not displayed.

member.remarks: By default this property is false. In that case when user clicks on the track, the increases or decreases its by . When this property is set to true, it moves the thumb directly to the click position.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SplitView.View1MinWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum width or height of the first panel.

remarks.para: Use this property to specify the mimimum width or height of the first panel. When is Horizontal, this property specifies the mimimum width. When is Vertical, this property specifies the mimimum height.
For example, if is set to 20 and is Vertical, then user will not be able to drag the splitter to reduce the height of the first panel to be less than 20.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.SplitView.View1Width
member.summary: Gets or sets the initial width or height of the first panel.

remarks.para: Use this property to specify the initial width or height of the first panel. When is Horizontal, this property specifies the initial width of the first panel. When is Vertical, this property specifies the initial height of the first panel.
You can use "star size" with this property. For example, if is set to "1*" and is set to "2*", then the second panel would receive twice of the space as the first panel.
This property is ignored if is set.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TreeView.ItemBorderStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the styles to be applied to the outside element around a 's text area.

remarks.para: This property is typically used to customize the style of an when the item is selected. The following XAML is the default :
remarks.code: <Style TargetType="Border"> <Setter Property="Background" Value="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource Mode=FindAncestor, AncestorType={x:Type my:TreeViewItem}}, Path=Background}"></Setter> <Setter Property="BorderBrush" Value="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource Mode=FindAncestor, AncestorType={x:Type my:TreeViewItem}}, Path=BorderBrush}"></Setter> <Setter Property="BorderThickness" Value="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource Mode=FindAncestor, AncestorType={x:Type my:TreeViewItem}}, Path=BorderThickness}"></Setter> <Setter Property="Padding" Value="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource Mode=FindAncestor, AncestorType={x:Type my:TreeViewItem}}, Path=Padding}"></Setter> <Style.Triggers> <DataTrigger Binding="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource Mode=FindAncestor, AncestorType={x:Type my:TreeViewItem}}, Path=IsSelected}" Value="True"> <Setter Property="Background" Value="{DynamicResource {x:Static SystemColors.HighlightBrushKey}}"/> <Setter Property="TextBlock.Foreground" Value="{DynamicResource {x:Static SystemColors.HighlightTextBrushKey}}"/> </DataTrigger> <MultiDataTrigger> <MultiDataTrigger.Conditions> <Condition Binding="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource Mode=FindAncestor, AncestorType={x:Type my:TreeViewItem}}, Path=IsSelected}" Value="True"></Condition> <Condition Binding="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource Mode=FindAncestor, AncestorType={x:Type my:TreeViewItem}}, Path=IsSelectionActive}" Value="False"></Condition> </MultiDataTrigger.Conditions> <Setter Property="Background" Value="{DynamicResource {x:Static SystemColors.ControlBrushKey}}"/> <Setter Property="TextBlock.Foreground" Value="{DynamicResource {x:Static SystemColors.ControlTextBrushKey}}"/> </MultiDataTrigger> </Style.Triggers> </Style>
remarks.para: The above style applies different background and foreground color based on the values of the 's and property.

member.summary: Gets or sets the expand delay in millisecond.

remarks.para: Use this property to specify the amount of time (in milliseconds) between mouse is positioned over a menu item and the sub menu expands. The default value is 0.
This property is ignored if is set to true.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.MenuBase.CollapseDelay
member.summary: Use this property to specify the amount of time (in milliseconds) between user moving mouse out of a sub menu and the sub menu close.
member.remarks: The default value is 300. So the sub menu closes shortly after the mouse has left the sub menu. Setting this value to 0 to disable this behavior.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the is selected. This is a depdency property.
member.value: true if the is selected; otherwise false. The default value is false.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabItem.TabStripPlacement
member.summary: Gets the tab strip placement of the parent . This a dependency property.
member.value: One of the enumeration values. The default value is .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabItem.HeaderString
member.summary: Gets or sets a string value that represents this 's corresponding 's in the dropdown menu. This is a dependency property.
member.value: The default value is null.

remarks.para: EO.Wpf can display a drop down menu that contains a menu item for each tab item. User can select a menu item from this drop down menu to select the corresponding tab item. By default, if no value is given to HeaderString, the scans the header content/template for any visual element, and build a string value based on the 's property, then use this string for the menu item text. The shortcoming of this approach is that if there is no element in the header content/template, then the result value will be an empty string.
Assigning a value to the HeaderString property ensures that this is properly represented in the dropdown menu.

example.para: The following example demonstrates how this property is used:
example.code: <Window x:Class="Test.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:eo="http://schemas.essentialobjects.com/wpf/" Title="MainWindow" Height="350" Width="525"> <Grid> <eo:TabControl x:Name="TabControl" DropDownMenuMode="Always"> <eo:TabItem HeaderString="Red"> <eo:TabItem.Header> <Rectangle Fill="Red" Margin="2" Width="50" Height="20" /> </eo:TabItem.Header> </eo:TabItem> <eo:TabItem HeaderString="Green"> <eo:TabItem.Header> <Rectangle Fill="Green" Margin="2" Width="50" Height="20" /> </eo:TabItem.Header> </eo:TabItem> <eo:TabItem HeaderString="Blue"> <eo:TabItem.Header> <Rectangle Fill="Blue" Margin="2" Width="50" Height="20" /> </eo:TabItem.Header> </eo:TabItem> </eo:TabControl> </Grid> </Window>
example.para: The following image shows the result:

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.TabItemOverflowStrategy
member.summary: Specifies the strategy a uses to arrange tab items when tab items exceeding one row.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.TabItemOverflowStrategy.Wrap
member.summary: Wrap the items into multiple row.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.TabItemOverflowStrategy.Clip
member.summary: Hide the items that can not be fully displayed and displays a drop down button at the end of the tab item row. Clicking the drop down button opens a drop down menu that allows user to switch tabs.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.TabItemOverflowStrategy.Scroll
member.summary: Add a scroller at the end of the tab item row. User can use the scroller to scroll the tab items towards left or right.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.TabItemOverflowStrategy.Shrink
member.summary: Automatically shrink the tab items so that they can still fits in one row.

member.name: T:EO.Wpf.DropDownMenuMode
member.summary: Specifies the visibility level of a 's dropdown menu button.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.DropDownMenuMode.Always
member.summary: The dropdown menu button is visible for all overflow strategies.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.DropDownMenuMode.Auto
member.summary: The dropdown menu button will only be visible for the required overflow strategies.

member.name: F:EO.Wpf.DropDownMenuMode.None
member.summary: The dropdown menu is not visible at all.

member.value: One of the enumeration values. The default value is .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabControl.HeaderTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the HeaderTemplate property. This is a dependency property.
member.value: The default value is null.

remarks.para: The property represents a shortcut for not individually defining the of each contained in this instance.

The following example uses an array of color strings as the items source of the , and then the HeaderTemplate property is used to provide a common template with color preview at the header.
<Window x:Class="Test.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:eo="http://schemas.essentialobjects.com/wpf/" xmlns:sys="clr-namespace:System;assembly=mscorlib" Title="MainWindow" Height="350" Width="450"> <Grid> <Grid.Resources> <x:Array x:Key="Themes" Type="sys:String"> <sys:String>Blue</sys:String> <sys:String>Green</sys:String> <sys:String>Silver</sys:String> </x:Array> </Grid.Resources>
<eo:TabControl ItemsSource="{StaticResource Themes}"> <eo:TabControl.HeaderTemplate> <DataTemplate> <StackPanel Orientation="Horizontal"> <Rectangle Width="22" Height="22" Fill="{Binding}" Margin="0,0,6,0" /> <Label Content="{Binding}" ContentStringFormat="{}{0} Theme" VerticalAlignment="Center" /> </StackPanel> </DataTemplate> </eo:TabControl.HeaderTemplate> </eo:TabControl> </Grid> </Window>
The following image shows the result:

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabControl.NewTabButtonStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the for the new tab button. This is a dependency property.

remarks.para: When is set to true, the displays an additional button of type next to the last tab item. Clicking that button triggers the event if the Items collection is being populated explicitly, or the event if is used instead.
See here for more information on how to use this property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabControl.ShowNewTabButton
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to display a button next to the last tab item that allows user to add new tab items. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to show the new tab button next to the last ; otherwise false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: Note that the new tab button can be styled via the property.
See here for more information on how to use this property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabControl.ShowCloseTabButton
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to display a close button on each tab item. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to show a close button on each tab item; otherwise false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: The 's close button can be styled via property.
See here for more information on how to use this property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabControl.CloseTabButtonStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the style applied to 's close button. This is a dependency property.

remarks.para: must be set to true in order to display the close button. The target type for this style is .
See here for more information on how to use this property.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabControl.OverlapDepth
member.summary: Gets or sets the overlap depth. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A value that represents the space in pixels that a will overlap with it on its adjascent . The default value is 0.

remarks.para: This property is usually used when the tab button is not rectangle. For example, the built-in "Chrome" skin uses this property so that the tab button overlaps with each other.
Note that in case a negative value is given, it will be coerced to 0.

example.para: The following example sets the OverlapDepth to 5:
example.code: <Window x:Class="Test.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:eo="http://schemas.essentialobjects.com/wpf/" Title="MainWindow" Height="250" Width="350"> <DockPanel Margin="5"> <eo:TabControl eo:ThemeManager.SkinName="Chrome" OverlapDepth="5"> <eo:TabItem Header="Header1" /> <eo:TabItem Header="Header2" /> <eo:TabItem Header="Header3" /> <eo:TabItem Header="Header4" /> </eo:TabControl> </DockPanel> </Window>
example.para: The following image shows the result:

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TabControl.AutoRotate
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the items header is auto-rotated or not. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to auto-rotate the tabItem header; otherwise false. The default value is false.

remarks.para:
Note that the TabItem's is only rotated via XAML in the default style once the following conditions are met:
The property is set to true.
The property is set to either or .

example.para: The following example illustrates the effect of using this property:
example.code: <Window x:Class="EO.Demos.MainWindow" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation" xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml" xmlns:eo="http://schemas.essentialobjects.com/wpf/" Title="TabControl Development" Height="200" Width="400"> <Grid> <eo:TabControl AutoRotate="True" TabStripPlacement="Left"> <eo:TabItem Header="Header 1"></eo:TabItem> <eo:TabItem Header="Header 2"></eo:TabItem> </eo:TabControl> </Grid> </Window>
example.para: The following image shows the result:
If was not set to true, the the tab item headers "Header 1" and "Header 2" would be horizontal.

member.name: E:EO.Wpf.TabControl.NewItemRequested

See here for more information on how to use this event.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ProgressBar.IsPercent
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the is computed as a percentage. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to compute the as a percentage; otherwise, false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: Note that in order to use this property, the property must be set to true.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ProgressBar.ContentTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the used to format the content of the . This is a dependency property.
member.value: The default value is null.

remarks.para: Note that in order to use this property, the property must be set to true.
If is not enough to show the information required, you can use the ContentTemplate to construct rich content inside the .

In the following example, we are going to construct a simple progress bar that shows the number of files downloaded from a repository:
<eo:ProgressBar x:Name="ProgressBar" VerticalAlignment="Center" Height="23" Minimum="0" Maximum="200" Value="135" ShowContent="True"> <eo:ProgressBar.ContentTemplate> <DataTemplate> <StackPanel Orientation="Horizontal"> <TextBlock VerticalAlignment="Center" Text="Downloaded " /> <TextBlock VerticalAlignment="Center" Text="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource FindAncestor, AncestorType=eo:ProgressBar}, Path=DisplayValue}" /> <TextBlock VerticalAlignment="Center" Text=" files out of " /> <TextBlock VerticalAlignment="Center" Text="{Binding RelativeSource={RelativeSource FindAncestor, AncestorType=eo:ProgressBar}, Path=Maximum}" /> </StackPanel> </DataTemplate> </eo:ProgressBar.ContentTemplate> </eo:ProgressBar> The previous XAML markup produces the following result:

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ProgressBar.ContentTemplateSelector
member.summary: Gets or sets the a template selector that enables custom template-selection logic. This is a dependency property.
member.value: The default value is null.

remarks.para: Note that in order to use this property, the property must be set to true.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ProgressBar.ContentStringFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets a string format that is used to format the display value. This is a dependency property.
member.value: A string format value that is used to format the display value. The default value is '{0}'.

remarks.para: Note that in order to use The ContentStringFormat property, the property must be set true and no template is being used.

The following example shows how to change the ContentStringFormat property:
<eo:ProgressBar Minimum="0" Maximum="100" Value="35" VerticalAlignment="Center" ShowContent="True" ContentStringFormat="{}{0}% Completed."></eo:ProgressBar>
The previous code produces the following result:

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ProgressBar.DisplayValue
member.summary: Gets the display value that is used as the . This is a dependency property.

remarks.para: Note that by default the DisplayValue has the same value as , but when the property is set to true, The internally compute the percentage of the based on and and store it in . For example, if is 0, and is 200 and is 100, then will be 50.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ProgressBar.ContentPresenterStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the applied to the content presenter. This is a dependency property.

remarks.para: Note that in order to use this property, the property must be set to true.
This style is primarly used to update the foreground property of the content presenter, because the is using the property to change the brush of the progress indicator.

The following example, changes the foreground of the content to DarkOrange and the progress indicator brush to Orange:
<eo:ProgressBar Minimum="0" Maximum="100" Value="65" VerticalAlignment="Center" Foreground="Orange" ShowContent="True"> <eo:ProgressBar.ContentPresenterStyle> <Style TargetType="ContentPresenter"> <Setter Property="TextElement.Foreground" Value="OrangeRed" /> </Style> </eo:ProgressBar.ContentPresenterStyle> </eo:ProgressBar> The previous XAML markup produces the following result:

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ProgressBar.ShowContent
member.summary: Gets or sets a values that indicates whether the supports rich content in its client area or not. This is a dependency property.
member.value: true to show rich content; otherwise false. The default value is false.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ListBoxItem.AllowDragCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether during a drag and drop operation this can be copied.

remarks.para: This property is inheritable. It can inherit value from the 's property.

By default this property is false, which means a drag and drop operation can only move the item to a different location. When this property is set true, user can hold down control key to copy the item to a different location.
This property is ignored if a 's data item is the itself (as in the case when are statically defined in XML, as oppose to populating the ListBox from a data source). User can not copy a in this case.

member.name: M:EO.Wpf.ThemeManager.RegisterSkinStyles(EO.Wpf.SkinStyleInfo[])
member.summary: Register a list of skin styles.
member.param: A list of objects that contain information about the styles.

remarks.para: Use this function to register custom skins. A custom skin is a named style for a specific control type. Once a skin is registered, it can be applied either directly through attached property, or indirectly through attached property or property.
All skins and thems must be registered before they can be used, so you must register them skins as early as possible, such as in your App class's constructor.

member.name: M:EO.Wpf.ThemeManager.RegisterThemeStyles(EO.Wpf.ThemeStyleInfo[])
member.summary: Register a list of themes styles.
member.param: A list of objects that contain information about the styles.

remarks.para: Use this function register custom themes. A theme is a collection of rules that defines the skin to be used for each type of controls. Each donates such a rule. This allows you to associate different theme to the same skin. For example, while a control typically have two different skins for "Classic" and "Aero", a control uses the same skin for both themes.
All skins and thems must be registered before they can be used, so you must register them skins as early as possible, such as in your App class's constructor.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.TreeViewItem.AllowDragCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether during a drag and drop operation this can be copied.

remarks.para: This property is inheritable. It can inherit value from a parent item's property or from the 's property.

By default this property is false, which means a drag and drop operation can only move the item to a different location. When this property is set true, user can hold down control key to copy the item to a different location.

This property is ignored if a 's data item is the itself (as in the case when are statically defined in XML, as oppose to populating the TreeViewItem from a data source). User can not copy a in this case.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.IsEditable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that enables or disables editing of the text in text box of the .
member.remarks: When is set to true, the creates a in the selection box to allow user to enter text directly (when is false), or select and copy item text (when is set to true).

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.IsReadOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the control inside the selection box is read-only.
member.remarks: When is set to true, the creates a in the selection box. By default, user can enter text directly in the textbox. However if is set to true, user can no longer do so. User will still be able to select an item from the drop down, and once an item appears in the selection box, user will be able to select and copy item text.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.IsSelectionBoxHighlighted
member.summary: Gets whether the is highlighted.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.StaysOpenOnEdit
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a that is open and displays a drop-down control will remain open when a user clicks the textbox.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.IsDropDownOpen
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the drop-down for a combo box is currently open.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.IsSelectedItemsDropDownOpen
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the drop-down for selected items is currently open.

remarks.para: This property is different than . EO can display two different drop-downs: one contains all items, the other only contains selected items when is true. The purpose of the second drop down is display all selected (checked) items so that user can uncheck them. This property indicates whether the second drop down is open.
See Multi-Selection for ComboBox for more details about this feature.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.SelectionBoxItem
member.summary: Gets the item that is displayed in the selection box.
member.remarks: The uses this property to show the selected item in the . To get the selected item(s) of the control, use property or property respectively.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.EmptyPrompt
member.summary: Get the object to be displayed when the is empty.
member.remarks: Use this property to offer a visual feedback and hint to the user when the is empty. For example, you can set it to "-- Please select a city --" for a "City" drop down. It is possible to use for this property. See using empty prompt for more details about this feature.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.DropDownMaxItemCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum items to be displayed in the dropdown.
member.remarks: If both and are set, takes priority over . Also the value of this property is suggestive in nature --- the may not be able to honor this value sometimes. For example, if different items have different height, then as user scrolls the drop down list, the number of visible items will change, thus making maintain a fixed number of visible items impossible.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.DropDownMaxWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum width for the drop-down of the .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.DropDownMaxHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum height for the drop-down of the .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.DropDownMinWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum width for the drop-down of the .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.DropDownMinHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum height for the drop-down of the .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the text of the currently selected item or the text entered by the user.

remarks.para: This property is only used when is false. When multi-selection is enabled ( is true). You can not use this property to change the text of the selection box. In that case if you wish to get the text of the selected items, you can use the following code:
remarks.code:
'Get the first selected item Dim item As Object = ComboBox1.SelectedItems(0)
'Get the ComboBoxItem object for this item Dim comboBoxItem As ComboBoxItem = DirectCast(ComboBox1.ItemContainerGenerator.ContainerFromItem(item), ComboBoxItem)
'Get the item text Dim itemText As String = comboBoxItem.Text

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.SelectionBoxItemTemplate
member.summary: Gets the item template of the selection box content.
member.remarks: Use this property to customize the appearance of the item when it appears inside the selection box. It is particularly useful if you wish to customize the delete button of the selected item when is set to true. See here for an example about how to use this feature.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.MultiSelectionItemTemplate
member.summary: Gets or Sets the item template of the Multi selection Item's content.
member.remarks: Use this property to customize the appearance of the item when it appears inside the selection box. It is particularly useful if you wish to customize the delete button of the selected item when is set to true. See here for an example about how to use this feature.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.SelectionBoxItemStringFormat
member.summary: Gets a composite string that specifies how to format the selected item in the selection box if it is displayed as a string.
member.remarks:
This property returns the format string that is used to format the current selected item. The property value is usually derived from another property value. For example, for the following ComboBox:
<eo:ComboBox xmlns:sys="clr-namespace:System;assembly=mscorlib" ItemStringFormat="MMMM d, yyyy"> <sys:DateTime>2004/3/4</sys:DateTime> <sys:DateTime>2004/8/9</sys:DateTime> <sys:DateTime>2005/10/14</sys:DateTime> <sys:DateTime>2005/4/8</sys:DateTime> </eo:ComboBox>
ItemStringFormat "MMMM d, yyyy" is used to format each item and the selected item. In this case SelectionBoxItemStringFormat returns "MMMM d, yyyy".

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.DropDownExpandEffect
member.summary: Gets or sets the effect played when the drop down opens.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.DropDownCollapseEffect
member.summary: Gets or sets the effect played when the drop down closes.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.DropDownBorderStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the style of the drop down border.

remarks.para: Use this property to set the style of the drop down border. For example, the following code sets the drop down border color to blue:

Note that because the style is applied as a whole, you may need to have multiple setters in your style even if you only want to change a single property. For example, the above sample sets both BorderBrush and BorderThickness. If you only set BorderBrush, then no border will be shown because BorderThickness has a default value 0 when not set.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.ShowClearButton
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to display a clear button.
member.remarks:
A "clear" button can be displayed immediately prior to the drop down button to allow user to clear the content of the . This property is only used when multi-selection is not enabled (when is false).
See Using Clear Button for more details about this feature.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.ClearButtonTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the template for the clear button.
member.remarks: The clear button is only displayed when is true. See Using Clear Button for more details about this feature.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.MoreItemsButtonTemplate
member.summary: Gets or sets the template for the "more items" button.
member.remarks: "More Items" button is displayed when user has selected multiple items, but the selection box does not have enough room to display all items. In this case, the displays a "More Items" button immediately prior to the drop down button. Clicking "More Items" button opens a drop down window that displays all selected items. User can then unselect any selected items from the drop down.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.ComboBox.SelectedItems
member.summary: Gets the currently selected items.
member.remarks: Use this property to get all the selected items when is true.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome._AP.IsClientElement
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether an element inside a 's title area should be treated as if it is in the client area.
member.remarks: By default, user can drag mouse in the title area moves the window. Setting an element's WindowChrome.IsClientElement to true disables this behavior and allow the control to define its own mouse behaviors. Usually you should set this property to true if an element is inside the window's title area (within area defined by property or ) but you wish it to have normal mouse behavior instead of the default dragging behavior. For example, if you have a inside the title area and you would like it to behave like a button, then you should set this property to true.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Sets the value of the for a specified .

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome.EnableChrome
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether chrome is enabled on the containing window.
member.remarks: Setting this property to false to turn off chrome on the containing window as if the element didn't exist. The default value is true.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome.EnableGlass
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to enable aero glass effect on the window.

remarks.para: When aero glass is enabled on the window, the window's title and frame area are blended with existing desktop image to create a frosted glass effect. The default value is true if the system supports glass effect and it is not turned off. Otherwise this property returns false.
When this property returns false, is displayed to create a window frame.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome.CornerRadius
member.summary: Gets or sets the corner radius of the window.
member.remarks: This property is only used when is false.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome.FrameThickness
member.summary: Gets or sets the window frame thickness.
member.remarks: This property controls the amount of space reserved on each side of the window between the outter edge of the window and the outter edge of the window content. If the window is resizable, the frame area is also the resizing area.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome.TitleHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the window title height.

remarks.para: This property determines the height of the window title, which allows user to move the window by dragging the title.
To pevent a dragging operation on an element that's inside the window's title area from being intepreted as moving the window, you must set attach property on the element to true.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome.TitleElement
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the title element.
member.remarks: This property is only used when is not explicitly set. When this property is used, area above 's bottom edge is regarded as window title area.

member.name: P:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome.FrameTemplate
member.summary: The template to be applied on the whole window when glass is not supported by the current system.

remarks.para: Use this template to create a border style for the window on system that does not support glass (for example, on Windows 2003 system) or when glass effect has been turned off.

member.name: M:EO.Wpf.WindowChrome.CreateChromedWindow
member.summary: Dynamically creates a chromed window from code behind.
member.remarks: The of the is a object. You must add your window content as the content of the object.

member.returns: The newly added control if the doesn't already have one, or an existing control in the if one already exists.
